comments.commentBody: Kile, actually you need to learn some history. Your great grandparents did not in all likelihood have to have any papers. When this country was founded, it was founded as an open borders state. You just needed to come and settle and would become a citizen. This was done by design. The founders of this nation knew that the best are those that take risks, leave it all behind, and commit to a future somewhere else.
My dog loves the Joy of Painting -- Bob Ross's soothing voice and the sound of the brushes on the canvas puts her right to sleep. She also prefers Nature on PBS or anything with wild animals.
Then he better start kicking in for the cable bill!

interesting!  my cat seems to absolutely love bach.  i left her alone recently with the 60 cds of bach cantatas running continuously and plenty of dry food and water and a clean litter box -- and returned 3 days later to find her perfectly content and apparently hardly bothered by my absence.

Our cat loved piano music, but it had to be live. She'd spend as much time as she could on the piano bench when my kids practiced, or even when I attempted something myself. She'd tolerate the learning of new pieces, but especially loved it when they became more polished with practice.

Now the kids and the cat are gone. Thanks for the memories.
My border collie prefers music, specifically, Sheryl Crow and Bach.

Why call vaccines "safe"? They are safe, no quotation marks. Severe adverse reactions are extremely rare and DO NOT include autism. I'll go down your post point by point, but basically vaccines are a common good with a very tiny chance of harming an individual.

Hannah Poling didn't have autism, she had a mitochondrial disorder. It presented in much the same way as autism, but it is an entirely different disease/syndrome. A vaccine triggered it, but so could a cold, or the flu, or any other event that triggered a strong immune response.

Yes, vaccines have rare side effects that can be very dangerous, even deadly. On the other hand, the diseases we immunize for generally have much higher death and disability rates.

As to your specific questions: diptheria used to be found in this country- vaccination is why it is no longer endemic. Vaccines give protection against diseases, but it isn't 100%, so it's best never to be exposed. Young children get rubella, and are around potentially pregnant women, so it's best to immunize everyone and create "herd" immunity. If no one gets rubella, they can't pass it on to pregnant women.

As for hepatitis B, it is transmitted by sex or blood. That means a that if a child is around someone who has hep B and doesn't know it (not a rare occurrence), s/he could contract it through a cut, or by sharing a toothbrush or razor.
Great shots! As an avid underwater photographer, I wish my shots were 1/1,000,000 as good as these!
Might be worth looking at Li Wei in Beijing who explores a very similar motif.  For example, look at his Hanging Conflict series from 2010.
Whew! I'm exhausted just reading that!
I buy it, and it didn't cost a fortune in other people's money to come to a sensible conclusion.

I have a different theory: Proto-humans were inveterate pot smokers until, at some remote stage of our development, the proto-DEA made marijuana unavailable. Trying by any means to recapture their long accustomed state of intoxication, running was discovered to produce similar sensations, albeit at a much reduced level.
The rarity of predators and abundance of food made running largely unneccesary and our fledgling faculties made even contriving a reason a painful exercise. This left only the most intelligent and pleasure hungry members to run, and to be ever more inventive in devising reasons why. Eventually, whole battles were staged, just so a "messenger" could run home to inform of victory.

Did they really need to use ferrets? I can think of another animal that is unlikely to run unless something is chasing it or it's chasing something, sleeps 18-20 hours a day, and doesn't need to be released into the wild afterwards. In short, a cat. Though anyone trying to get a cat onto a treadmill had better be wearing protective gear.

To answer the question about why running and not other forms of exercise, people have been distance running to catch food far longer than they have been doing most other activities. Prehistoric man wasn't about to hop on his Schwinn and bike down that mammoth.

................so many ways to get high.  Maybe this is why Forest Gump kept running.   I think running is great for some people but I think that like any activity it can be over done,  I knew a man who ran his way through engineering school -- it was his main form of exercise; and by the time he was in his mid-twenties his doctor told he literally had the feet of a man who was twenty years older.  He had worn out his feet, literally.
wow!  What a great first sentence..  This person can write.

Intense exercise only feels good if one is in good shape, physiologically speaking.  But as modern, "civilized" human beings, most of us are in terrible health.  It's positively *painful* for most of us to exercise intensely, and for many people, even to exercise moderately.  So it's not a surprise at all that we're so immobile.

When in public High School i 'practiced' for sports activities each afternoon, and also attended a 'phys ed' class daily.

One pattern became inescapably obvious: on the days when social&academic activities were found to be more difficult than normal (generally felt poor/tired/weak) , phys-ed and sports practices were relatively effortless, and more pleasant than normal.

To this day i find athletic/aerobic activities therapeutic when other aspects are dismal.

The problem in your read is that you're assuming purpose or intent. One can easily say that endocannabinoids mask discomfort and encourage running, but for neither goal; their existence simply has to not be a reproductive or survival hinderance, then they can be passed on without evolutionary tax.

If they happen to encourage a slightly more fit and survivable human, then they probably offset their cost and tend to stick around, I doubt they prefer your narcotic effect or exercise, they are, after all, chemicals.

My 2cents btw, all the major discomfort i feel associated with running pops up when the cannabinoids are gone--two days after big boy long runs with intervals. I'm generally pain free whist running, and the effect of the endocannabanoids in my life seems to be far more of a post-run sartorial effect...hardly narcotic, more opiate.

I would agree with this. I imagine endocannabinoids are not simply a reward but a kind of "anesthetic" for the stresses placed on the body, similar to how the brain can dull the pain of extreme trauma, such as a crushed or severed limb. Sure, it hurts, but not at the intensity of the initial insult.
And that's why you don't enjoy it. Try viewing it as a mini vacation from life, work, family, whatever. A chance to observe nature (if outdoors) or a chance to think and daydream uninterrupted.

I enjoyed many of the comments you posted.  You made some great points 1) running or any exercise for that matter can be very therapeutic.  Forget about everyone and everything else and focus on yourself for a little while.  2) running / exercise takes time to get to the point where it feels good.  Be consistent.  Focus on technique (self-awareness).  3) don't over do it.  3-4 runs weekly is perfect.  Less than 3 may not help progression.  More than 5 may lead to too much breakdown from not enough recovery in between.

I run but I don't feel a "high" in the way suggested by the article. I simply feel better as the run progresses. I know neurobiology is at work, and I'm thankful for it. I look forward to that feeling when I've settled into the run, the joints are no longer complaining, and I can just float along comfortably.

It took a long time -- probably a year or more of consistent running 3 or 4 times per week -- for me to build up the fitness to reach the point where this phenomenon occurred. Still, the first mile is ALWAYS hard, as though the body is saying, "Wait, are you sure this is a good idea? It kind of hurts!" Now I know the discomfort will pass, as long as I've done my job and am listening to my body and know that I'm not injured or pushing too hard. Running takes a lot more practice, self-awareness, and (especially) patience than many people realize.

I think this is why many people don't stick with running. They expect it to feel good sooner than it actually does. Not only during a given run, but over time.
The best part of this article are the comments.
Ferrets are weird for sleeping 18 hours a day in a burrow? Move over, ferrets. My Greyhound sleeps 20 hours a day on my sofa (at 5 years old), because that's what Greyhounds do. Running, schmunning.

I think it's about reaching an equilibrium. We need enough of a positive biological incentive to run but need enough of a negative incentive to ensure that we don't over do it either.  Over exercising can obviously create problems (i.e. sprains, tears, etc.) and also amenhorrea in women.
No, armo, those were exo-cannabinoids!

As I recall, there is another way endocannabinols can get in the bloodstream. It involves Bob Marley songs and an antiquated peoples' movement from the last century. I am not sure if ferrets were involved. At least I don't remember any except for those ferret leggers we would visit now and then.
That's what he just showed: Running supplies it's own internal system of rewards, namely endocannabinoids.

It does nothing of the sort. Where do you think this internal system of rewards is located? Where and how do you think these choices are made?

It is an unfortunate but necessary conclusion of modern science (not neurology or biology, though, so don't blame them-it's just classical mechanics) that, yes, life is deterministic. There is no "choice" or "freewill" in the sense you mean it. But you needn't accept that to appreciate this study.

The scientists here aren't having a thing to do with choice or freewill. What they're trying to ascertain is the WHERE and HOW of the internal system of rewards and "choices" you mention. They clearly don't disagree with you. They're just, forgive them, aware that the mind is the brain.

"Dr. Raichlen wondered if the endocannabinoids had had a more momentous role in the development of mankind as a whole. Had we continued to run, as a species, not because we had to run, but because we had become hard-wired to like it?"
This sounds like the experimental hypothesis of a scientist who is having a hard time reconciling his perception of running as a painful and unpleasant (and "metabolically costly") activity with the fact that quite a few humans enjoy running with out a gun pointed to their heads (or without the evolutionary threat of extinction pointed at their heads). Looking for neurobiological or evolutionary causes for why people like to run seems overly deterministic and dismisses the power of individual choices. Could it be that running supplies its own internal system of rewards? Could it be one of those things in life that gives you exactly what you put into it? In this respect it is no more determined by evolutionary causes than working to become an artist or poet or concertmaster violinist or cabinetmaker.
This is a ridiculous waste of money

I would like to recommend the free NAAFA Child Advocacy ToolkitSM (CATK) and other written guidelines/resources.

A Yale Rudd Center report reviewed existing research on weight stigma in children and adolescents, with attention to the nature and extent of weight bias toward obese youths and to the primary sources of stigma in their lives, including peers, educators, and parents. As a result of weight bias and discrimination, obese children suffer psychological, social, and health-related consequences. http://www.yaleruddcenter.org/resources/upload/docs/what/bias/StigmaObes...

Rebecca Puhl of the Rudd Center further brings to light the stigmatization of large children in the following article.
http://www.obesityaction.org/magazine/oacnews7/Childhood Obesity and Stigma.pdf

The NAAFA Child Advocacy Toolkit shows how Health At Every Size® takes the focus off weight and directs it to healthful eating and enjoyable movement. It addresses the bullying, building positive self-image and eliminating stigmatization of large children. The CATK lists resources available to parents, educators or caregivers for educational materials, curriculum and programming that is beneficial for all children. It can be found at:
http://issuu.com/naafa/docs/naafa_childadvocacy2011combined_v04?viewMode...

Again:  This article is talking about toddlers, not elementary-aged school children.  Agreed that elementary-aged school children are too old to need this kind of supervision on the playground-- but an 18-month-old?

Call me old fashioned, but I have no memory of riding on my parents' lap down a slide (or accompanying me on any piece of playground equipment). I probably would've died of embarrassment.

In the Atlanta GA elementary school I attended, we had huge (for us) swing sets that were all metal and could attain enormous heights. The only real danger was sitting on the solid metal seat at noon during the warmer months. You learned to wait until a few other bottoms had lowered the temperature to just below boiling before climbing aboard.

And as far as I know, not one child died or was injured because they were using the swing set without the accompaniment of an adult.
